pr_title: feat(JOML) replace perspective and ortho with JOML impl

timeline.message: feat(JOML) replace perspective and ortho with JOML impl

timeline.author: kBlaszczyk

timeline.message: added test cases for PerspectiveCameraTest and OrthogonalCameraTest

timeline.bodyText:
I haven't worked in this part of the code, so do let me know if there are standard practices to brush up on. But being new to this, my reaction on seeing a test like this is: wha?
This PR changes a value from 5.0273395 to -5.235E-1. Why? Is it to account  for an implementation change, necessary for the new version to pass? Or is it an adjustment to the test data that makes a better test case?
Where do these numbers with with four (or more) significant figures come from? Does it matter what they are, or are they arbitrary values the test is using as a starting place?
timeline.author: keturn

replies.bodyText: (I'm glad you moved those line-starting commas, though. 🙂 I don't think start-with-comma is a standard this repository follows.)
replies.author: keturn

replies.bodyText: used some random position and tested it with the old code and then moved it back to this. the test might not be necessary.
replies.author: pollend

replies.bodyText: we talked about this on discord and I agreed that if these methods are just calling through to joml's orthographic and perspective methods, we don't learn much by testing the arithmetic ourselves.
replies.author: keturn

timeline.bodyText:
Here we've got what looks to be the same values as in viewMatrix, almost.
Are those the same numbers, but displayed a little differently due to binary-floating-point vs decimal representations? Or is the change of 0.01% significant? Could this have been a copy of viewMatrix instead?
I don't believe it's necessary to remove all numbers from tests (in a math library, even!), but I'm failing to tell signal from noise here.
timeline.author: keturn

replies.bodyText: On a second reading, I see this test does have that camera.setOrientation with the 0.001 radian pitch and yaw, so maybe those tiny differences are significant?
replies.author: keturn

timeline.bodyText: I bet there's a way we can make this assertion method easier to read and give more useful output on fail. I think you're following established precedent here, so I certainly won't hold up a review on that, but maybe a little side project for sometime.
timeline.author: keturn
